cultures.name: Greco-Roman (Modern Western)
cultures.snippet: The basis for the 88 'official' constellations recognized today by the International Astronomical Union. They are rooted in the mythology of ancient Greece and Rome.

constellations.name: Orion
constellations.description: The Hunter. A prominent, easily recognizable constellation. In Greek myth, Orion was a giant hunter, often depicted battling Taurus the Bull or chasing the Pleiades.

constellations.name: Ursa Major
constellations.description: The Great Bear. It contains the famous asterism, the Big Dipper. In one Greek myth, the nymph Callisto was turned into a bear by Zeus to protect her from Hera's wrath.

constellations.name: Cassiopeia
constellations.description: The Queen. A 'W' or 'M' shaped constellation in the northern sky. In Greek mythology, Cassiopeia was punished by Poseidon for her vanity by being placed in the heavens.

constellations.name: Sagittarius
constellations.description: The Archer. A zodiac constellation representing a centaur with a bow and arrow. It's associated with the mythological centaur Chiron in some interpretations.

cultures.name: Ancient Chinese
cultures.snippet: The Chinese system divided the sky into four main symbolic animals (or 'Symbols'), each associated with a direction and a season. These were further divided into 28 Lunar Mansions and hundreds of smaller asterisms ('Xingguan').

constellations.name: Azure Dragon of the East (Cāng Lóng)
constellations.description: One of the Four Symbols, associated with Spring and the element Wood. It spans seven Lunar Mansions, representing parts of the dragon's body.

constellations.name: White Tiger of the West (Bái Hǔ)
constellations.description: One of the Four Symbols, associated with Autumn and the element Metal. It represents the fierce guardian of the western sky.

constellations.name: Tien Ta Tsaeng (Heaven's Great General)
constellations.description: A star group located in the area of the Western constellation Andromeda, often depicting a high-ranking military figure.

cultures.name: Diné (Navajo)
cultures.snippet: Navajo astronomy (Diné Siyizí) places constellations into categories like 'male,' 'female,' and 'traveling' groups, which play a role in traditional teachings and ceremonies. They focus on the functional and narrative aspects of the stars.

constellations.name: Átse E’tsoh (First Big One)
constellations.description: A northern constellation, often equated with the Big Dipper. It represents a male deity who instructs the people in the order and rules of the universe.

constellations.name: Gah Hóóyeel (Rabbit Tracks)
constellations.description: A group of stars that, when seen in the winter sky, signaled that winter was truly setting in. It’s part of a female deity's constellation, representing fertility and growth.

constellations.name: Átse Ats'oosí (First Slender One)
constellations.description: This is the Navajo interpretation of the stars that form the modern Western constellation Orion, seen as a bow-and-arrow-wielding warrior, symbolizing protection.
